verse: Jesus went to the Mount of Olives [east of Jerusalem across the Kidron Valley].
But ·early in the morning [at dawn] he went back to the Temple [courts; 2:14], and all the people came to him, and he sat and taught them.
The ·teachers of the law [scribes; experts in the law of Moses] and the Pharisees brought a woman who had been caught in adultery. They forced her to stand ·before [or in the midst of] the people.
They said to Jesus, “Teacher, this woman was caught ·having sexual relations with a man who is not her husband [in the very act of committing adultery].
The law of Moses commands that we stone to death every woman who does this [compare Lev. 20:10; Deut. 22:22–24]. What do you say we should do?”
They were asking this to ·trick [trap; test] Jesus so that they could have some ·charge [accusation] against him.

When they continued to ask Jesus their question, he ·raised up [straightened] and said, “Anyone here who ·has never sinned [is guiltless; is without sin] can throw the first stone at her [Deut. 13:9; 17:7; comp. Lev. 24:14].”
Then Jesus ·bent over [stooped down] again and wrote on the ground.
Those who heard Jesus began to leave one by one, first the ·older men [elders] and then the others. Jesus was left there alone with the woman standing before him.
Jesus ·raised up [straightened] again and asked her, “Woman [a respectful term of address in Greek; see 2:4], where are they? Has no one ·judged you guilty [condemned you]?”
She answered, “No one, sir.”

header: Jesus Is the Light of the World

verse: Later, Jesus talked to the people again, saying, “I am the light of the world [the Feast of Shelters included a lamp lighting ritual that Jesus may be alluding to; 7:37–39]. The person who follows me will never ·live [walk] in darkness but will have the light ·that gives life [of life].”

The Pharisees [see 1:24] said to Jesus, “When you ·talk [testify; witness] about yourself, ·you are the only one to say these things are true. We cannot accept what you say [your testimony/witness is not true/valid; 5:31].”

Jesus answered, “Yes, I am ·saying these things [witnessing; testifying] about myself, but they are true [valid]. I know where I came from [from the Father or “from above”] and where I am going. But you don’t know where I came from or where I am going.
You judge ·by human standards [according to the flesh; rather than guided by the Spirit]. I am not judging anyone.
But ·when [if] I do judge, ·I judge truthfully [my judgment is true], because I am not alone. The Father who sent me is with me.
Your own law says that ·when two witnesses say the same thing, you must accept what they say [the testimony of two witnesses is true/valid; Deut. 17:6; 19:15].
I am one of the witnesses who speaks about myself, and the Father who sent me is the other witness.”
[Therefore] They asked him, “Where is your father?”

Jesus said these things while he was teaching in the Temple [courts], near ·where the money is kept [the treasury; offering box]. But no one ·arrested [seized] him, because ·the right time for him [his hour; see 2:4] had not yet come.

Again, Jesus said to the people, “I will leave you [when he dies, is raised, and ascends to the Father], and you will ·look for [seek; search for] me, but you will die in your ·sins [sin; of unbelief]. You cannot come where I am going.”
So the Jews asked, “Will he kill himself? Is that why he said, ‘You cannot come where I am going’?”
Jesus said, “You people are from here below [from the earth], but I am from above [from heaven or from God]. You belong to this world, but I ·don’t belong to this world [am not of this world].

So I told you that you would die in your sins. Yes, you will die in your sins if you don’t believe that ·I am he [I am; this may be an allusion to God’s (Yahweh’s) self identification either from Ex. 3:14 (the great “I AM”) or Is. 40—55, where God repeatedly says, “I am he”)].”
[Therefore] They asked, “Then who are you?”
I have many things to say and ·decide about you [or condemn/judge you for]. But I tell ·people [the world] only the things I have heard from the One who sent me, and he speaks the truth.”
The people did not understand that he was talking to them about the Father.

So Jesus said to them, “When you lift up [on the cross] the Son of Man [a title for the Messiah; Dan. 7:13–14], you will know that ·I am he [I am; see 8:24]. You will know that these things I do are not ·by my own authority [on my own] but that I say only what the Father has taught me.
The One who sent me is with me. I always do what is pleasing to him, so he has not left me alone.”
While Jesus was saying these things, many people believed in him.
So Jesus said to the Jews who believed in him, “If you ·continue to obey my teaching [remain/abide in my word], you are truly my ·followers [disciples].
Then you will know the truth, and the truth will ·make [set] you free.”
They answered, “We are Abraham’s ·children [descendants; seed; Gen. 12:1–3], and we have never been anyone’s slaves. So why do you say we will be free?”
Jesus answered them, “·I tell you the truth [Truly, truly I say to you], everyone who ·lives in sin [commits/practices sin] is a slave to sin.
A slave does not ·stay with a family [live in the household] forever, but a son ·belongs to the family [lives in the household] forever.
So if the Son makes you free, you will be ·truly free [free indeed].

I know you are Abraham’s ·children [descendants; seed], but you ·want [are trying; seek] to kill me because ·you don’t accept my teaching [my word has no place in you; thus showing they were Abraham’s children only physically, not spiritually; Jer. 9:25–26; Rom. 9:7; Gal. 4:21–31].
I am telling you ·what my Father has shown me [what I have seen in the Father’s presence], but you do what ·your father [or the Father] has told you.”
They answered, “Our father is Abraham.”
I am a man who has told you the truth which I heard from God, but you are trying to kill me. Abraham did nothing like that.
So you are doing the things your own father did.”
Jesus said to them, “If God were really your Father, you would love me, because I came from God and now I am here. [For] I did not come ·by my own authority [on my own]; God sent me.
You don’t understand [Why don’t you understand…?] what I say, because you cannot ·accept my teaching [hear my word/message].

You ·belong to [are from] your father the devil, and you want to do what he wants. He was a murderer from the beginning [Gen. 3; Rom. 5:12] and ·was against the truth [does not uphold the truth], because there is no truth in him. When he tells a lie, ·he shows what he is really like [he reveals his own nature; or he speaks his own language; he speaks from his own], because he is a liar and the father of lies.
But because I speak the truth, you don’t believe me.
·Can any of you [Who among you can…?] ·prove that I am guilty [convict me] of sin? If I am telling the truth, why don’t you believe me?
The person who belongs to God ·accepts what God says [hears/obeys the words of God]. But you don’t ·accept what God says [hear; obey], because you don’t belong to God.”
·They [The Jewish leaders; The Jews] answered, “We say you are a Samaritan [a people disliked by the Jews; 4:4, 9] and ·have a demon in you [are demon-possessed]. Are we not right?”
Jesus answered, “I ·have no demon in me [am not demon-possessed]. I give honor to my Father, but you dishonor me.
I am not trying to get ·honor [glory] for myself. There is One who wants this ·honor [glory] for me, and he is the judge.
·I tell you the truth [Truly, truly I say to you], whoever ·obeys my teaching will never die [keeps my word will never see death].”

[Therefore] ·They [The Jewish leaders; The Jews] said to Jesus, “Now we know that you ·have a demon in you [are demon-possessed]! Even Abraham and the prophets died. But you say, ‘Whoever ·obeys my teaching will never die [keeps my word will never taste death].’
Do you think you are greater than our father Abraham, who died? And the prophets died, too. ·Who do you think you are [or Who are you claiming/pretending to be]?”
Jesus answered, “If I give ·honor [glory] to myself, that ·honor [glory] is worth nothing. The One who gives me ·honor [glory] is my Father, and you say he is your God.
You don’t really know him, but I know him. If I said I did not know him, I would be a liar like you. But I do know him, and I ·obey what he says [keep his word].
Your father Abraham ·was very happy [rejoiced] that he would see my day [the day of the Messiah’s arrival]. He saw that day and was glad.”
[Therefore] ·They [The Jewish leaders; The Jews] said to him, “You have never seen Abraham! You are not even fifty years old [Abraham had been dead for almost 2,000 years].”
Jesus answered, “·I tell you the truth [Truly, truly I say to you], before Abraham was even born, ·I am!” [A claim to deity; see comments at 8:24; 10:28.]
When Jesus said this, the people picked up stones to throw at him [believing he had committed blasphemy worthy of death]. But Jesus hid himself, and then he left the Temple.
